data.name: Yosemite National Park
data.description: Yosemite National Park is in California’s Sierra Nevada mountains. It’s famed for its giant, ancient sequoia trees, and for Tunnel View, the iconic vista of towering Bridalveil Fall and the granite cliffs of El Capitan and Half Dome.

subtrails.name: Vernal and Nevada Falls via the Mist Trials
subtrails.description: Vernal and Nevada Falls via the Mist Trail is a 8.8 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Yosemite Valley, California that features a waterfall and is rated as difficult. The trail is primarily used for hiking and is best used from May until October.

reviews.name: martha steward
reviews.reviewOfTrail: First part of trail was paved, offered beautiful views! We got to the part where Mist trail and John Muir trail split, and the mist trail was closed. We tried doing the John Muir trail, but switchbacks became too icy and were covered with snow.

reviews.name: John mason
reviews.reviewOfTrail: it was beautiful and a great place to spend time. absolutely love it but where the trail is supposed to take you is closed off so you have to take a detour and then it got really icy and slim before we got to the waterfalls so we had to take a stop. but great!

subtrails.name: Upper Yoesmite Falls Trail
subtrails.description: Upper Yosemite Falls Trail is a 7.6 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Yosemite Valley, California that features a waterfall and is only recommended for very experienced adventurers. The trail is primarily used for hiking.

reviews.name: martha steward
reviews.reviewOfTrail: First part of trail was paved, offered beautiful views! We got to the part where Mist trail and John Muir trail split, and the mist trail was closed. We tried doing the John Muir trail, but switchbacks became too icy and were covered with snow.

subtrails.name: Vernal Park
subtrails.description: Vernal Falls is a 4 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Yosemite Valley, California that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, and nature trips and is best used from May until November.

reviews.name: martha steward
reviews.reviewOfTrail: First part of trail was paved, offered beautiful views! We got to the part where Mist trail and John Muir trail split, and the mist trail was closed. We tried doing the John Muir trail, but switchbacks became too icy and were covered with snow.

data.name: Acadia
data.description: Looking for a great trail in Acadia National Park, Maine? AllTrails has 216 great hiking trails, trail running trails, mountain biking trails and more, with hand-curated trail maps and driving directions as well as detailed reviews and photos from hikers, campers, and nature lovers like you. Ready for some activity? There are 123 moderate trails in Acadia National Park ranging from 0.9 to 27.1 miles and from 16 to 1,525 feet above sea level. Start checking them out and you'll be out on the trail in no time!

subtrails.name: Beehive Loop Trail
subtrails.description: Acadia National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are $30 per vehicle or $25 per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is $15 per person. You can also purchase a park specific annual pass for $55. A steep climb to the top of this small mountain with wonderful views out over the Atlantic and surrounding Acadia hills. The Beehive Trail is a very popular moderate to difficult out and back or loop trail using iron rungs on ledges of exposed cliffs, and is very steep, offering spectacular views of Sand Beach and the surrounding area at Acadia National Park.  Start just north of and across the One way loop road from the Sand Beach parking area, climbing steps and through the forest to some exposed fairly flat rocky areas and a tall cairn of rocks marking your next steps.  Be sure to look for the light blue (Carolina Blue) trail markers as the trail can be quickly lost in your enthusiasm to scale the cliffs.  Stay on trail as strategically placed iron rungs, bridges and hand and foot holds take the technical part out of the climb.  Once at the top you can opt to go down the back side and make it a loop or go down the way you came.

reviews.name: Noah Desmarais
reviews.reviewOfTrail: Steep hike but so beautiful

reviews.name: Anthony R
reviews.reviewOfTrail: it was beautiful and a great place to spend time. absolutely love it but where the trail is supposed to take you is closed off so you have to take a detour and then it got really icy and slim before we got to the waterfalls so we had to take a stop. but great!

subtrails.name: Cadillac North Ridge Trail
subtrails.description: Cadillac North Ridge Trail is a 4 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Bar Harbor, Maine that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.

reviews.name: Lindsey Clive
reviews.reviewOfTrail: Majority of the trail is walking on ice. Make sure to have on the proper gear.  The road is closed so you have to walk either the road or the Kebo Trl to the trailhead. Only adds ~0.5 mile round trip.

reviews.name: Lisa Strainer
reviews.reviewOfTrail: A buddy and I went up today for our first time doing this trail. It was great, but you need micro spikes for sure. We jumped on the road 3/4 of the way up, but that was because we couldn’t find the blue markers for the trail. Took the road up which added a good amount of distance to the trail. Took the entire trail back down. Great experience and amazing views

subtrails.name: Precipice, Orange and Black and Champlain North Ridge Loop
subtrails.description: Precipice, Orange and Black and Champlain North Ridge Trail Loop is a 2.1 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Bar Harbor, Maine that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as difficult. The trail is primarily used for hiking, nature trips, and bird watching and is best used from May until October.

reviews.name: Sophie Mcllan
reviews.reviewOfTrail: First part of trail was paved, offered beautiful views! We got to the part where Mist trail and John Muir trail split, and the mist trail was closed. We tried doing the John Muir trail, but switchbacks became too icy and were covered with snow.

reviews.name: Jactyn Hagis
reviews.reviewOfTrail: it was beautiful and a great place to spend time. absolutely love it but where the trail is supposed to take you is closed off so you have to take a detour and then it got really icy and slim before we got to the waterfalls so we had to take a stop. but great!

data.name: American Samoa
data.description: A large reservoir formed by Theodore Roosevelt Dam on the Salt River in Arizona as part of the Salt River Project.

subtrails.name: Mount Alava Trail
subtrails.description: Mount 'Alava Trail is a 6.1 mile moderately trafficked out and back trail located near Pago Pago, Tutuila, American Samoa that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, nature trips, and bird watching and is accessible year-round.

reviews.name: Kerry Bailey
reviews.reviewOfTrail: After 62 national parks and hiking 100's of trails, some day hikes and many multiple nights I would put this in my bottom 10.  The trail is moderate even with the slippery rock after it rains.  the bird sounds are amazing. BUT this could be so much more.  it is kind of a boring hike.  10 foot wall of green on both sides of the trail. There are maybe 3 or 4 good viewpoints when with some planning there could be many more.  The view at the top was disappointing.  The NPS in their infinite wisdom to not ever harm nature, have let plants start to block the view point about 25 to 30%.  My less than 5' tall wife had to climb on the wall for the view.

reviews.name: Sam Vandewater
reviews.reviewOfTrail: I would consider this trail difficult after it rains for those who are not strong hikers or sure-footed because of how slippery it is. The beginning is a little steep but then the grade becomes fairly moderate for the remainder of the trail. You end of at the top of the ridge overlooking Pago Pago harbor and Rainmaker Mountain. There were a few coconut crabs along the trail and sensitive plants that have leaves that quickly close if you touch them. The views were amazing from the top. There is a small cover building that allows you to take a break from the sun/rain.

subtrails.name: Lower Sauma Ridge Trail
subtrails.description: Lower Sauma Ridge Trail is a 0.4 mile lightly trafficked out and back trail located near Pago Pago, Tutuila, American Samoa that features beautiful wild flowers and is good for all skill levels. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, nature trips, and bird watching and is accessible year-round.

reviews.name: Caitlin Worrell
reviews.reviewOfTrail: First part of trail was paved, offered beautiful views! We got to the part where Mist trail and John Muir trail split, and the mist trail was closed. We tried doing the John Muir trail, but switchbacks became too icy and were covered with snow.

reviews.name: Sam Vandewater
reviews.reviewOfTrail: Have to take a detour and then it got really icy and slim before we got to the waterfalls so we had to take a stop. but great!

subtrails.name: Pola Island Trail
subtrails.description: Pola Island Trail is a 0.6 mile moderately trafficked out and back trail located near Pago Pago, Tutuila, American Samoa that features beautiful wild flowers and is good for all skill levels. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, nature trips, and bird watching and is accessible year-round.

reviews.name: Caitlin Worrell
reviews.reviewOfTrail: Unfriendly dogs can be a big challenge in American Samoa, so we drove past the last house. We pulled over a bit too early to park because the map indicated that we were already about half way down the trail. There is amole parking where the three informational signs. The beach had large rocks so it would be challenging without appropriate footwear. There were lovely views of Pola Island were a very short walk from the parking area. We met the high talking chief on the beach who warned us not to get too close to the water due to strong waves and currents.

reviews.name: Kevin Mora
reviews.reviewOfTrail: Short walk to the water’s edge where waves crash hard against the shoreline. No problems with dogs on the way in and a few barked as we left. Just stay off their property and motion like you are picking up a rock to throw at them and they will keep their distance. 5/9/18

data.name: Badlands
data.description: Looking for a great trail in Badlands National Park, South Dakota? AllTrails has 14 great hiking trails, views trails, wildlife trails and more, with hand-curated trail maps and driving directions as well as detailed reviews and photos from hikers, campers, and nature lovers like you. Just looking to take a quick stroll? We've got 7 easy trails in Badlands National Park ranging from 0.8 to 4.5 miles and from 2,411 to 2,742 feet above sea level. Start checking them out and you'll be out on the trail in no time!.

subtrails.name: Notch Trail
subtrails.description: Notch Trail is a 1.3 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Interior, South Dakota that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, nature trips, and bird watching and is best used from March until October.

reviews.name: Griffin Lang
reviews.reviewOfTrail: Nice and short out and back. Good quick way to get into the badlands and feel the size of the rock (dirt?) towers. Leads to a cool overlook with a couple other off trail places to explore. Ladder is fun, a bit shakey but nothing too bad. The lady in front of us did it with no hands.

reviews.name: Joy Lyn
reviews.reviewOfTrail: I wasn’t sure about this when I saw the ladder, but there are great views at the top and well worth the climb.

reviews.name: Brie Stahl
reviews.reviewOfTrail: Went early in the morning around sunrise. There was not a soul on the trail the entire time we were there. Gorgeous views of the buttes, and an overlook at the end. Really loved this trail the most of all the Badlands hikes I did.

subtrails.name: The Door Trail
subtrails.description: The Door Trail is a 0.8 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Interior, South Dakota that features beautiful wild flowers and is good for all skill levels. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, and nature trips and is best used from April until October.

reviews.name: Anna Wondra
reviews.reviewOfTrail: Broadwalk is very nice.

reviews.name: Brie Stahl
reviews.reviewOfTrail: Starts as a easy board walk and leads into the buttes. You follow little trail markers until the “end of trail sign” gorgeous 360 views of the buttes that surround you. Loved this hike. Would recommend doing this if you see badlands!

subtrails.name: Castle Trail
subtrails.description: Castle Trail is a 10.5 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Interior, South Dakota that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is best used from April until October.

reviews.name: Luke din
reviews.reviewOfTrail: really nice all together. great barren views. it was pretty wet and muddy because the snow is all melting but there were big sections where that wasn’t a problem. lost the trail a few times on the way in but after i really focused on finding the red marker poles it was fine. some of it was extremely slippery but that became more fun than anything to be honest. also, the alleged dog defection comes from coyotes.

reviews.name: James Hayne
reviews.reviewOfTrail: Cool out and back hike through large rock formations. There is an option to take the northern part through the prairie, and while not hard, not as pretty as the southern section.   On the south side you can also take a quick detour to look out over Saddle Pass.  We started early in the morning (Sept) after doing the Notch/Window/Door trails to beat the heat since there is zero shade. We wrapped up around noon and it was getting quite toasty so I wouldn't recommend doing this midday/afternoon.

data.name: Big Bend
data.description: Mount LeConte via Rainbow Falls Trail is a 13 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Gatlinburg, Tennessee that features a waterfall. The trail is only recommended for very experienced adventurers and is primarily used for hiking and nature trips.

subtrails.name: Lost Mine Trail
subtrails.description: Lost Mine Trail is a 4.9 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Big Bend National Park, Texas that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking and is accessible year-round..

reviews.name: martha steward
reviews.reviewOfTrail: First part of trail was paved, offered beautiful views! We got to the part where Mist trail and John Muir trail split, and the mist trail was closed. We tried doing the John Muir trail, but switchbacks became too icy and were covered with snow.

reviews.name: Joseph mark
reviews.reviewOfTrail: it was beautiful and a great place to spend time. absolutely love it but where the trail is supposed to take you is closed off so you have to take a detour and then it got really icy and slim before we got to the waterfalls so we had to take a stop. but great!

subtrails.name: The Window trail
subtrails.description: Upper Yosemite Falls Trail is a 7.6 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Yosemite Valley, California that features a waterfall and is only recommended for very experienced adventurers. The trail is primarily used for hiking.

subtrails.name: Emory Peak via South Tim Trail and Boot Spring Trail
subtrails.description: Vernal Falls is a 4 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Yosemite Valley, California that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, and nature trips and is best used from May until November.

reviews.name: martha steward
reviews.reviewOfTrail: First part of trail was paved, offered beautiful views! We got to the part where Mist trail and John Muir trail split, and the mist trail was closed. We tried doing the John Muir trail, but switchbacks became too icy and were covered with snow.

reviews.name: mark jo
reviews.reviewOfTrail: This is the best mid-length hike in the park, in my opinion.  Even at 15.5miles (3 miles Emory Peak Spur) I would rate this at the low end of difficult.  The climbs and descents do not have the large steps as on other trails.  Highly recommend this trail.

data.name: Biscayne
data.description: Located in Biscayne Bay, this park at the north end of the Florida Keys has four interrelated marine ecosystems: mangrove forest, the Bay, the Keys, and coral reefs. Threatened animals include the West Indian manatee, American crocodile, various sea turtles, and peregrine falcon.
